Stem: Upright, branching, with backward-pointing stiff hairs.
Leaves: Rosette leaves up to 30 cm long with 3-7 pairs of lobes. Smaller leaves higher up. Also covered in stiff backward-pointing hairs.
Flowers: Typical Mustard family (Brassicaceae) flowers with 4 yellow petals up to 8 mm long.
FruitSeeds: Long narrow 7-12 cm long pods covered in stiff hairs. On stalks that point away from stem giving spread out appearance.
Habitat: Disturbed areas, roadsides, pastures, riparian areas, forests.
DistinguishingFeatures: Very difficult to distinguish from numerous others in Mustard family (Brassicaceae), so expert advice is advised. May be distinguished from other *Sisymbrium* species by its long, rougly hairy fruit.
